tweet: Today in #BlackHistoryMonth I’m recognizing Johnnie Carr, a #shero from Montgomery who never stopped fighting for equality. Ms. Carr was central to planning the Montgomery Bus Boycott, and served as Montgomery Improvement Association president after Martin Luther King Jr. pic.twitter.com/2ZJB2nHRhl

Today we demanded more than thoughts and prayers – we demanded action. I’m proud to co-sponsor the Bipartisan Background Checks Act and with it’s passage today, we proved that we will not stand by while gun violence rips apart our communities. #HR8 https://twitter.com/politico/status/1100860480032333824 …

This weekend we will mark the 54th anniversary of Bloody Sunday. I hope the @FaithNPolitics Pilgrimage will help us reflect on all that we can do to advance justice and equality in our nation. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/wTXiwfZUKH

The foot soldiers of the Civil Rights Mvmt marched, fought and died for the right to vote & one of my greatest honors was passing a bill to award them a Congressional Gold Medal. In introducing the Voting Rights Advancement Act today, I am proud to protect & advance their legacy. pic.twitter.com/lTrtIRsv31

Voting is the cornerstone of our democracy. Everything starts with the vote – representation, districting & policies that impact every single American. 

We must restore the Voting Rights Act of 1965 to ensure every American can make their voice heard! https://thehill.com/blogs/congress-blog/politics/431509-for-a-more-perfect-union-restore-the-voting-rights-act …

Heartbreaking news out of Montgomery today where a 17-year-old was shot at school. I am praying for the victim’s full recovery. 

It’s time to enact common sense gun safety to keep our communities safe. Americans have a right to not live in fear of this type of violence. https://twitter.com/aldotcom/status/1100457513454059522 …

A strong democracy removes barriers and improves access, so EVERY citizen can vote.

We MUST restore the VRA and #RestoreTheVote
That’s why 207 of my House colleagues and I are introducing legislation today to #RestoreTheVote by putting the teeth back into the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

Since the Supreme Court’s Shelby decision, changes to some state voting laws are leading the United States in the wrong direction. When Americans are not able to cast their ballot, their voices are left behind. #RestoreTheVote
I am proud to stand with my colleagues @speakerpelosi @senschumer @repjohnlewis @senatorleahy @sendougjones today to stand up for voting rights! #RestoreTheVote pic.twitter.com/LDWRloz6vI

.@repjohnlewis and so many other Americans – fortified by their quest for justice – were beaten bloody during Bloody Sunday in 1965. He is a constant inspiration in our fight for equality and justice every day. #BlackHistoryMonth

As we approach the 54th anniversary of Bloody Sunday, I want to recognize my friend and colleague @rejohnlewis, the “boy from Troy,” who is always getting into what he calls the good kind of trouble! #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/BUGUELYKwq

Our democracy depends on every American being able to make their voice heard through the ballot box. That’s why I’m leading the charge to #RestoreTheVote. https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2019/feb/24/we-should-be-outraged-alabama-congresswoman-tackles-voter-suppression …
My staff honored the brave men and women of the Selma and Dallas County police today for their dedication day in and day out to make our community safer. Thank you!! pic.twitter.com/2Qwt8y2Kdj

Civil rights lawyer Fred Gray worked tirelessly to advance justice throughout AL and the South. He defended Rosa Parks, @NAACP and many others, promoting justice throughout Alabama and the South, and led the legal charge to integrate @AuburnU. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/ZVt2Yp8qNc

Richard C. Boone was a civil rights activist who spent his life fighting for justice and equality. Mr. Boone is perhaps best known for his work organizing the Selma to Montgomery marches, where led 800 students to Montgomery to join MLK and 25,000 marchers. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/iYeuTfXW1c
Mr. Sutton has made a lot of poor decisions, but stepping down is the right thing to do. Now, he must apologize. https://twitter.com/ByChipBrownlee/status/1099029635311067136 …

Today we honor the thousands of ordinary Americans who participated in the #MontgomeryBusBoycott, including the nearly 100 who were arrested on this day 63 yrs ago. These ordinary Americans’ sacrifice and courage in the name of justice will never be forgotten. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/zH6yw7FkBP
Thanks to all who attending our Town Hall meeting in Bessemer tonight! Great turnout and awesome discussion! #ThisIsWhatDemocracyLooksLike pic.twitter.com/GsMd5N6Txw

Great meeting with @HICAtweets today about protecting TPS and our #Dreamers. Dreamers are our neighbors, friends, coworkers and church members. Above all, they are Alabamians who have only ever known the United States as home. pic.twitter.com/0ei16IUnv6

During WWII, African Americans in many states were still subject to discriminatory Jim Crow laws and the American military was racially segregated, but the airmen’s impressive combat record and achievements paved the way for full integration of the US military. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/iMnBiANv47

Today in #BlackHistoryMonth, I’m highlighting the great Tuskegee Airmen! They were the first African-American military aviators in the U.S. Armed Forces and some of the best pilots in the U.S. Army Air Forces. pic.twitter.com/b3GKTOx7px

Dr. Juanakee Adams is the first African-American female optometrist to practice in Alabama. Living by the saying "unto much is given, much is required," Dr. Adams gives back by mentoring young optometrists as they launch their careers. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/8LREel9e7l

Reverend Fred Shuttlesworth was a fearless freedom fighter and tenacious Civil Rights leader who always stood up for what was right. Despite multiple attempts on his life, Shuttlesworth persevered and reminded his family and community to always forgive. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/GgubJZAUBh

Next week, I will introduce HR 4, the Voting Rights Advancement Act, to help address the most egregious forms of voter suppression, like GA saw in Nov 2018 when the Republican candidate for gov put 53,000 voter registrations on hold, nearly 70% of which belonged to black voters. pic.twitter.com/ADTWsFYieo

.@StaceyAbrams testified abt her experience in the GA House and as a candidate for governor. I am in Atlanta, Georgia today taking part in a congressional field hearing on voting rights! pic.twitter.com/9VJGy4B8Fs

For the millions of people of color who have been terrorized by white supremacy, this kind of “editorializing” about lynching is not a joke – it is a threat. These comments are deeply offensive and inappropriate, especially in 2019.  Mr. Sutton should apologize and resign. https://twitter.com/itsmelissabrown/status/1097640505758937088 …

Joe Louis, known as the “Brown Bomber,” was one of the best heavyweight boxers of all time. He reigned as the world heavyweight champion from 1937 to 1949 and had a career record of 66 wins and 3 losses! #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/7oj39Ns3yJ
As Alabama’s first black Congresswoman, I stand on the shoulders of giants like Jackson who fought, bled and died for the right to vote. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/WbV8tRSb6p

Jackson was inspired by Dr. King to help advance the civil rights movement and, before his death, he tried repeatedly to register to vote, but could not due to discriminatory Jim Crow laws. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/0EEdzVEk6n

Today, on #JimmieLeeJacksonDay, I'm recognizing Jimmie Lee Jackson who was beaten and killed by police in a peaceful civil rights march. He was just 26 years old. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/eT2y6w52pG

Attorney Oscar Adams was a trailblazer who was no stranger to “firsts.” He was the first African-American Alabama Supreme Court justice and the first African American elected to statewide office in Alabama. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/tQSp6kafuj

One of the first bills I got signed into law honored Addie Mae, Cynthia, Carole and Denise with a Congressional Gold Medal, the highest honor Congress can bestow upon a civilian. I was honored to attend the bill signing with President @BarackObama and the girls' relatives. pic.twitter.com/IrBSw2JoSA

The lead perpetrator – a Klan leader who boasted about his role – was not brought to justice for more than 10 years after the bombing. Nearly 40 years later, @SenDougJones prosecuted the two remaining suspects. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/ZjrsYGjQFV
The bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church was the third in 11 days after a federal court order had come down mandating the integration of Alabama’s school system. #BlackHistoryMonth

At 10:22 a.m. on the morning of September 15, 1963, Addie Mae Collins, Cynthia Wesley, Carole Robertson and Denise McNair were killed by white supremacists who bombed Birmingham’s 16th Street Baptist Church. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/MEsdTXHT1q

Over 90% of rural hospital closures have been in states that didn’t expand Medicaid before the closure. This is the 7th rural hospital in AL to close in 8 years. Do the math! The President should support the bipartisan, bicameral deal that House and Senate leaders struck this week to keep the government open and avoid another #TrumpShutdown. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/12/us/politics/border-wall-deal.html …

During the last government shutdown, 62% of federal workers depleted most or all of their savings; 42% took on debt; 25% borrowed from retirement accounts; and 25% visited a food bank. Vivian Malone was the first African American to graduate from the University of Alabama. Despite attempts by Gov. George Wallace to block her enrollment and violent threats to her safety, she persisted, helping shape the University of Alabama we know today. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/9ZsLgGvmxq

Montgomery native Nat King Cole rose to international fame during the 1950s. His many hits like "The Christmas Song" and "L-O-V-E" have withstood the test of time, making him a household name. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/vjyq4mjaPM

Daniel "Chappie" James Jr. was an American fighter pilot in the Air Force, who became the first African American General to pin on four stars. He was a product of Alabama's Tuskegee Institute and instructed the legendary Tuskegee Airmen during World War II. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/9ufUCjySTx

Alice Coachman Davis was the first black woman to win an Olympic gold medal! Davis had to overcome many disadvantages growing up under discriminatory Jim Crow laws, but persevered and captured high jump gold in 1948. 

#BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/yQoMG0fJhb

My prayers are with the Dingell family today. Former Congressman John Dingell was a giant in the House. May he Rest In Peace. https://twitter.com/NBCNews/status/1093696853101735936 …

Sen. @JaboWaggoner is right! We need to expand Medicaid in Alabama. Premiums and health care costs are higher in states that have not expanded. Sgt. Carter's service truly represents the best of Alabama’s 7th District. I’m honored his wife Mrs. Tiphanie Carter will join me tomorrow at the #SOTU. My congressional colleagues need to hear her story and act to prevent the senseless gun violence afflicting our communities.

This #SOTU I am honored to pay tribute to the bravery and sacrifices of our law enforcement officers. Sgt. Wytasha Carter was the kind of man that we all hope our sons grow up to be – a devoted and passionate father, husband, co-worker and member of the Birmingham community. pic.twitter.com/A60ouAqCOI

Happy 106th Birthday, Rosa Parks! 

Parks’ legacy reminds us that one small, bold action can cause great change. May we always summon her strength and courage as we continue to fight for justice. 

#BlackHistoryMonth https://www.nbcnews.com/news/nbcblk/rosa-parks-birthday-5-things-you-may-not-know-about-n716516 …
He famously said, “I don't know what the future may hold, but I know who holds the future,” a reminder that we all have a role to play in advancing justice and equality.

Ralph Abernathy was one of Dr. Martin Luther King’s closest friends and advisors whose work was central to the Montgomery bus boycott and the civil rights movement. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/V3zBqHNaxA

Birmingham native Condoleezza Rice was the first female African-American Secretary of State and the first woman to serve as National Security Advisor to the President.

#BlackHistoryMonth2019 pic.twitter.com/RrdvGpe7Y4

Wonderful being in Montgomery this morning speaking with civil rights icons Doris Crenshaw and Lisa McNair, whose sister Denise was a victim of the 16th Street Baptist Church Bombing, about how we can continue to advance Civil Rights in Alabama and our nation. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/vziJTgSxFm
